Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Situation2: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Story: We were walking home from school, my stepbrother and I, the late afternoon sun casting long shadows on the sidewalk. I kept an eye on him, as Mom always asked, making sure he didn’t wander too close to the curb or get distracted by his phone. That was my job as his stepbrother—look out for him, keep him safe. But my phone buzzed again, a string of messages from my girlfriend lighting up the screen. She was upset about our weekend plans, thinking I’d forgotten, and wanted to talk it out right now. As her boyfriend, I was supposed to resolve things quickly, not let misunderstandings fester. I felt the pressure mounting—my brother was skipping ahead, almost at the crosswalk, and my girlfriend’s texts were getting more insistent. I couldn’t be in two places at once. My heart pounded as I tried to decide: do I call out to my brother, or do I stop and text my girlfriend back? Both needed me, but I couldn’t figure out how to be what they each expected at the same time.
